Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Patellofemoral Arthroplasty and Total Knee Arthroplasty for Severe Patellofemoral Osteoarthritis

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 100 patients with debilitating symptoms and isolated patellofemoral disease were recruited from 2007 to 2014.

Participants.evidence: 100 patients with debilitating symptoms and isolated patellofemoral disease were recruited from 2007 to 2014.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either PFA or TKA.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the outcomes of patellofemoral arthroplasty (PFA) and total knee arthroplasty (TKA) in patients with severe patellofemoral osteoarthritis.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the area under the curve (AUC) for SF-36 bodily pain over 2 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either PFA or TKA.

Blinding.evidence: Randomisation was blinded for the first year and quasi-blinded to assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 100 patients with debilitating symptoms and isolated patellofemoral disease were recruited from 2007 to 2014.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The AUC for SF-36 bodily pain was significantly better for PFA (9.2 months, SD 4.3) compared to TKA (6.5 months, SD 4.5; p = 0.008).

Harms.evidence: Two revisions occurred in the PFA group. No significant difference in complications was observed.
